docs.title: Power CLI
docs.text:
A command-line tool for generating PowerPoint presentations programmatically.

Power CLI lets you create professional slide decks from YAML/JSON specifications, use templates, and automate presentation generation - all from your terminal.

docs.title: Why Power CLI?
docs.text:
• Automation: Generate presentations from data without touching PowerPoint
  • Templates: Use your corporate templates with placeholder replacement
  • Version Control: Store presentation specs in YAML alongside your code
  • Batch Generation: Create multiple presentations from different data sources
  • Reproducibility: Same input always produces the same output

docs.title: Create a presentation with a template
docs.text: power create deck.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx --title "Q1 Report"

docs.title: Generate from YAML
docs.text: power generate slides.yaml -o presentation.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx

docs.title: Inspect template layouts
docs.text: power inspect Galaxy.pptx

docs.title: Interactive mode
docs.text: power new -t Galaxy.pptx -o my_deck.pptx

docs.title: REST API
docs.text: Power includes a FastAPI-based REST API for generating presentations over HTTP.

docs.title: Live Service
docs.text:
The API is deployed on Google Cloud Run:

Base URL: https://power-api-944767079044.us-central1.run.app

Swagger UI: Open Documentation

docs.title: Endpoints
docs.text: Endpoint Method Description /health GET Health check /generate POST Generate presentation from JSON /generate-with-template POST Generate with uploaded template /inspect POST Inspect template layouts /batch/generate POST Batch generation (up to 50)

docs.title: GET /health
docs.text: Check API health status.

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "status": "healthy",
  "version": "0.1.7"
}

docs.title: Example
docs.text: curl https://power-api-944767079044.us-central1.run.app/health

docs.title: POST /generate
docs.text: Generate a presentation from a JSON specification.

docs.title: Request Body
docs.text:
{
  "title": "My Presentation",
  "subtitle": "Optional subtitle",
  "slides": [
    {
      "type": "content",
      "title": "Slide Title",
      "bullets": ["Point 1", "Point 2"]
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Response
docs.text: Returns the generated .pptx file as a binary download.

docs.title: Example
POST /generate-with-template
docs.text: Generate a presentation using an uploaded template file.

docs.title: Request
docs.text:
Content-Type: multipart/form-data

Field Type Description template File Template .pptx file spec String JSON specification filename String Output filename (optional)

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
curl -X POST "https://power-api-944767079044.us-central1.run.app/generate-with-template" \
  -F "template=@Galaxy.pptx" \
  -F 'spec={"title": "Themed Deck", "slides": [{"type": "content", "title": "Hello", "bullets": ["Styled slide"]}]}' \
  -F "filename=themed.pptx" \
  --output themed.pptx

docs.title: POST /inspect
docs.text: Inspect a template to see its layouts and placeholders.

docs.title: Request
docs.text:
Content-Type: multipart/form-data

Field Type Description template File Template .pptx file

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
{
  "template": "Galaxy.pptx",
  "slide_count": 13,
  "layout_count": 15,
  "slide_width": "12192000",
  "slide_height": "6858000",
  "layouts": [
    {
      "index": 0,
      "name": "Title Only Slide",
      "placeholders": [
        {"idx": 0, "type": "CENTER_TITLE (3)", "name": "Title 1"}
      ]
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
curl -X POST "https://power-api-944767079044.us-central1.run.app/inspect" \
  -F "template=@Galaxy.pptx"

docs.title: POST /batch/generate
docs.text: Generate multiple presentations in a single request.

docs.title: Request Body

{
  "items": [
    {
      "spec": {
        "title": "Presentation 1",
        "slides": [{"type": "content", "title": "Slide 1", "bullets": ["A", "B"]}]

docs.title: Weekly Status Report
docs.text:
Generate a weekly status report from data:

# weekly_status.yaml
title: Weekly Status Report
subtitle: "Week of {{WEEK_DATE}}"

slides:
  - type: content
    title: Completed This Week
    bullets:
      - "{{COMPLETED_1}}"
      - "{{COMPLETED_2}}"
      - "{{COMPLETED_3}}"

  - type: content
    title: In Progress
    bullets:
      - "{{INPROGRESS_1}}"
      - "{{INPROGRESS_2}}"

  - type: content
    title: Blockers
    bullets:
      - "{{BLOCKER_1}}"

  - type: content
    title: Next Week
    bullets:
      - "{{NEXT_1}}"
      - "{{NEXT_2}}"

Generate and fill:

power generate weekly_status.yaml -o status.pptx -t Corporate.pptx
power replace status.pptx \
    "WEEK_DATE=January 15, 2024" \
    "COMPLETED_1=Finished feature X" \
    "COMPLETED_2=Fixed bug Y" \
    "COMPLETED_3=Updated documentation" \
    "INPROGRESS_1=Working on feature Z" \
    "INPROGRESS_2=Code review for PR #123" \
    "BLOCKER_1=Waiting on API access" \
    "NEXT_1=Complete feature Z" \
    "NEXT_2=Start integration testing" \
    -o weekly_report.pptx

docs.title: Generate from CSV Data
docs.text:
Python script to generate presentations from CSV:

import csv
from pathlib import Path
import subprocess
import yaml

# Read CSV data
with open('customers.csv') as f:
    customers = list(csv.DictReader(f))

# Generate a presentation for each customer
for customer in customers:
    # Create YAML spec
    spec = {
        'title': f"Proposal for {customer['company']}",
        'subtitle': f"Prepared for {customer['contact']}",
        'slides': [
            {
                'type': 'content',
                'title': 'Our Solution',
                'bullets': [
                    f"Tailored for {customer['industry']}",
                    f"Budget: {customer['budget']}",
                    'Implementation in 30 days'
                ]
            },
            {
                'type': 'table',
                'title': 'Pricing',
                'headers': ['Service', 'Price'],
                'data': [
                    ['Setup', '$5,000'],
                    ['Monthly', '$500/mo'],
                    ['Support', 'Included']
                ]
            }
        ]
    }

    # Write YAML
    yaml_file = f"temp_{customer['id']}.yaml"
    with open(yaml_file, 'w') as f:
        yaml.dump(spec, f)

    # Generate presentation
    output = f"proposals/proposal_{customer['company'].replace(' ', '_')}.pptx"
    subprocess.run([
        'power', 'generate', yaml_file,
        '-o', output,
        '-t', 'Corporate.pptx'
    ])

    Path(yaml_file).unlink()  # Clean up

print(f"Generated {len(customers)} proposals")

docs.title: Shell Script for Multiple Reports
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

QUARTERS=("Q1" "Q2" "Q3" "Q4")
YEAR="2024"

for quarter in "${QUARTERS[@]}"; do
    power generate quarterly_template.yaml -o "reports/${quarter}_${YEAR}.pptx" -t Galaxy.pptx
    power replace "reports/${quarter}_${YEAR}.pptx" \
        "QUARTER=${quarter}" \
        "YEAR=${YEAR}" \
        -o "reports/${quarter}_${YEAR}.pptx"
    echo "Generated ${quarter} ${YEAR} report"
done

docs.title: Corporate Template Setup
docs.text:
1. Inspect your corporate template:
power inspect Corporate.pptx
  1. Note the layout names and indices:
0: Title Slide
1: Title and Content
2: Section Header
5: Title Only
6: Blank
7: Content with Caption
  1. Use specific layouts in YAML:
slides:
  - type: content
    title: Overview
    layout: "Title and Content"  # Use exact name
    bullets:
      - Point 1
      - Point 2

docs.title: Picture Placeholder Workflow
docs.text:
1. Find picture placeholders:
power inspect BrandedTemplate.pptx | grep -i picture

Output: 

├── idx=10 Picture Placeholder (PICTURE)
├── idx=11 Picture Placeholder 2 (PICTURE)

  1. Fill placeholders in YAML:
- type: content
  title: Our Team
  bullets:
    - Experienced professionals
    - Global presence
  placeholder_images:
    10: images/team.jpg
    11: images/office.jpg

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
# .github/workflows/generate-report.yml
name: Generate Report

on:
  schedule:
    - cron: '0 9 * * 1'  # Every Monday at 9 AM
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  generate:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.11'

      - name: Install Power CLI
        run: pip install nietzsche

      - name: Generate Report
        run: |
          power generate report.yaml -o weekly_report.pptx -t templates/Corporate.pptx
          power replace weekly_report.pptx \
            "DATE=$(date +%Y-%m-%d)" \
            "WEEK=$(date +%V)" \
            -o weekly_report.pptx

      - name: Upload Artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: weekly-report
          path: weekly_report.pptx

docs.title: Python Integration
docs.text:
from power import PowerPresentation

# Create programmatically
ppt = PowerPresentation(template="Galaxy.pptx")
ppt.clear_slides()

# Add slides
ppt.add_title_slide("Data Analysis", "Generated Report")
ppt.add_section_slide("Overview")
ppt.add_content_slide("Key Findings", [
    "Finding 1",
    "Finding 2",
    "Finding 3"
])

# Add chart
slide = ppt.add_slide(5)  # Title Only layout
slide.set_title("Trends")
slide.add_bar_chart(
    categories=["2021", "2022", "2023", "2024"],
    series_data={
        "Revenue": [100, 150, 200, 280],
        "Costs": [80, 100, 120, 150]
    }
)

ppt.save("analysis.pptx")

docs.title: Reusable Slide Components
docs.text:
Create partial YAML files and merge them:

import yaml

# Load components
with open('header.yaml') as f:
    header = yaml.safe_load(f)

with open('financials.yaml') as f:
    financials = yaml.safe_load(f)

with open('footer.yaml') as f:
    footer = yaml.safe_load(f)

# Combine
presentation = {
    'title': 'Combined Report',
    'slides': header['slides'] + financials['slides'] + footer['slides']
}

with open('combined.yaml', 'w') as f:
    yaml.dump(presentation, f)

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will have you creating PowerPoint presentations in 5 minutes.

docs.title: Step 1: Install Power CLI
docs.text:
uv tool install nietzsche

Or run directly without installing:

uvx --from nietzsche power --version

Verify the installation:

power --version

docs.title: Step 2: Create Your First Presentation
docs.text:
The simplest way to create a presentation:

power create my_first_deck.pptx --title "Hello World"

This creates a presentation with a single title slide.

docs.title: Step 3: Use a Template
docs.text:
Power CLI includes templates. Download one or use your own corporate template:

power create report.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx --title "Q1 Report" --subtitle "2024 Results"

docs.title: Step 4: Inspect Templates
docs.text:
Not sure what layouts are available? Inspect any PowerPoint file:

power inspect Galaxy.pptx

This shows all available layouts and their placeholders.

docs.title: Step 5: Generate from YAML
docs.text:
For more complex presentations, define your slides in YAML.

Create a file called slides.yaml:

title: My Presentation
subtitle: Getting Started with Power CLI

slides:
  - type: section
    title: Introduction

  - type: content
    title: What We'll Cover
    bullets:
      - Installing Power CLI
      - Creating presentations
      - Using templates
      - Advanced features

  - type: table
    title: Feature Comparison
    headers: [Feature, Status]
    data:
      - [Templates, Supported]
      - [Charts, Supported]
      - [Images, Supported]

  - type: chart
    title: Progress Over Time
    chart_type: bar
    categories: [Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4]
    series:
      Revenue: [100, 150, 200, 250]
      Costs: [80, 90, 100, 110]

  - type: title
    title: Thank You!
    subtitle: Questions?

Generate the presentation:

power generate slides.yaml -o presentation.pptx

Or with a template:

power generate slides.yaml -o presentation.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx

docs.title: Step 6: Interactive Mode
docs.text:
Prefer a guided experience? Use interactive mode:

power new -t Galaxy.pptx -o my_deck.pptx

Follow the prompts to build your presentation step by step.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and solutions when using Power CLI.

docs.title: Command not found: power
docs.text:
Symptom: Running power gives "command not found" error.

Solutions:

  1. Ensure the package is installed: 

    pip install nietzsche

  2. Check if pip scripts are in your PATH: 

    python -m power --help

  3. Try reinstalling with pipx: 

    pipx install nietzsche

docs.title: Import errors
docs.text:
Symptom: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pptx'

Solution: Install missing dependencies: 

pip install python-pptx click rich pyyaml pillow

Or reinstall the package: 

pip uninstall nietzsche
pip install nietzsche

docs.title: Template file not found
docs.text:
Symptom: Error: Invalid value for '-t' / '--template': Path 'template.pptx' does not exist.

Solutions:

  1. Check the file path: 

    ls -la template.pptx

  2. Use absolute path: 

    power create out.pptx -t /full/path/to/template.pptx

  3. Check current directory: 

    pwd

docs.title: Layout not found
docs.text:
Symptom: Layout specified in YAML doesn't work.

Solution: Inspect the template to see available layouts: 

power inspect template.pptx

Use the exact layout name from the output: 

- type: content
  layout: "Title and Content"  # Must match exactly

docs.title: Placeholder index error
docs.text:
Symptom: Warning: Could not fill placeholder 10: ...

Solution: 1. Find valid placeholder indices: 

power inspect template.pptx

  1. Use the correct index in your YAML: 
    placeholder_images:
  10: image.png  # Use idx from inspect output

docs.title: YAML parsing errors
docs.text:
Symptom: Error: while parsing a block mapping

Common causes:

  1. Incorrect indentation: 

    # Wrong
slides:
- type: content
  title: Test

# Correct
slides:
  - type: content
    title: Test

  2. Missing quotes around special characters: 

    # Wrong - colon causes issues
title: Revenue: Q1 Report

# Correct
title: "Revenue: Q1 Report"

  3. Tab characters (use spaces instead): 

    # Convert tabs to spaces
sed -i 's/\t/  /g' slides.yaml

docs.title: Chart data mismatch
docs.text:
Symptom: Chart looks wrong or error about data length.

Solution: Ensure series values match categories count: 

# Wrong - 4 categories but 3 values
categories: [Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4]
series:
  Revenue: [100, 200, 300]  # Missing one value!

# Correct
categories: [Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4]
series:
  Revenue: [100, 200, 300, 400]

docs.title: Permission denied
docs.text:
Symptom: Error: Permission denied: output.pptx

Solutions:

  1. Close the file if it's open in PowerPoint
  2. Check file permissions: 
    ls -la output.pptx
  3. Try a different output path: 
    power create ~/Desktop/output.pptx

docs.title: File is corrupted
docs.text:
Symptom: PowerPoint can't open the generated file.

Solutions:

  1. Check for errors during generation
  2. Verify template isn't corrupted: 
    power inspect template.pptx
  3. Try without a template: 
    power create test.pptx --title "Test"

docs.title: Image not found
docs.text:
Symptom: FileNotFoundError: Image not found: images/photo.png

Solutions:

  1. Use absolute paths: 

    image: /full/path/to/image.png

  2. Paths are relative to where you run the command: 

    cd /project/root
power generate slides.yaml -o out.pptx

  3. Check the file exists: 

    ls -la images/photo.png

docs.title: Slide index out of range
docs.text:
Symptom: Error: Slide index 5 out of range

Solution: Check slide count first: 

power inspect presentation.pptx
# Shows: Slides: 3
# Valid indices are 0, 1, 2

docs.title: Invalid replacement format
docs.text:
Symptom: Error: Invalid replacement format: name (expected KEY=VALUE)

Solution: Use the correct format: 

# Wrong
power replace deck.pptx name John -o out.pptx

# Correct
power replace deck.pptx NAME=John -o out.pptx

docs.title: JSON output parsing
docs.text:
Symptom: JSON output contains extra characters.

Solution: Use --json flag properly: 

# For piping to jq
power inspect template.pptx --json | jq '.layouts'

# For saving to file
power inspect template.pptx --json > info.json

docs.title: Slow generation with many images
docs.text:
Solutions:

  1. Optimize images before embedding: 

    # Resize large images
convert large.png -resize 1920x1080 optimized.png

  2. Use compressed formats (JPEG for photos)

  3. Process in batches for large presentations

docs.title: Memory errors with large templates
docs.text: Solution: Use simpler templates or split into multiple presentations.

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you can't resolve an issue:

  1. Check the GitHub Issues

  2. Create a new issue with:

  3. Power CLI version (power --version)
  4. Python version (python --version)
  5. Operating system
  6. Complete error message

  7. Minimal YAML to reproduce

  8. Include relevant files (sanitized of sensitive data)

docs.title: Debug Mode
docs.text:
For detailed error information, run Python directly:

from power import PowerPresentation
import traceback

try:
    ppt = PowerPresentation(template="template.pptx")
    # ... operations
except Exception as e:
    traceback.print_exc()

docs.title: YAML Format
docs.text: This page documents the complete YAML specification for power generate.

docs.title: Basic Structure
docs.text:
title: Presentation Title      # Creates title slide
subtitle: Optional Subtitle    # Subtitle for title slide

slides:                        # List of slides
  - type: content
    title: Slide Title
    bullets:
      - First bullet
      - Second bullet

docs.title: Top-Level Fields
docs.text: Field Required Description title No Presentation title (creates title slide if present) subtitle No Subtitle for title slide slides Yes List of slide definitions

docs.title: Title Slide
docs.text:
Creates a title slide (also created automatically from top-level title).

- type: title
  title: Welcome

docs.title: CLI Commands
docs.text: Power CLI provides commands for creating and manipulating PowerPoint presentations, both locally and via cloud API.

docs.title: Command Overview
docs.text: Command Description power create Create a new presentation with a title slide power generate Generate presentation from YAML/JSON specification power inspect Inspect template layouts and placeholders power new Interactive presentation builder power add Add a slide to an existing presentation power remove Remove a slide by index power replace Replace {{PLACEHOLDER}} text power cloud Generate presentations via cloud API

docs.title: Global Options
docs.text:
All commands support these options:

Option Description -h, --help Show help message and exit --version Show version (main command only)

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
Get help for any command:

# Main help
power --help
power -h

# Command-specific help
power create --help
power generate -h

docs.title: Using Templates
docs.text:
Most commands support the -t or --template option:

power create output.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx --title "My Deck"
power generate slides.yaml -o output.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx
power new -t Galaxy.pptx

docs.title: Output Files
docs.text:
Commands that create or modify presentations use -o or --output:

power generate slides.yaml -o presentation.pptx
power add deck.pptx -o updated.pptx --title "New Slide"
power remove deck.pptx 0 -o trimmed.pptx
power replace template.pptx NAME=John -o filled.pptx

docs.title: Chaining Commands
docs.text:
Combine commands for complex workflows:

# Create, then add slides
power create deck.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx --title "Report"
power add deck.pptx -o deck.pptx --title "Slide 2" --bullets "Point 1"
power add deck.pptx -o deck.pptx --title "Slide 3" --bullets "Point 2"

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text: Code Meaning 0 Success 1 Error (file not found, invalid input, etc.)

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Variable Description POWER_API_URL Override the default cloud API URL for power cloud commands

Example:

export POWER_API_URL=http://localhost:8080
power cloud health

docs.title: power add
docs.text: Add a slide to an existing presentation.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: power add PPTX_FILE -o OUTPUT --title TITLE [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Appends a new content slide to an existing PowerPoint presentation. Useful for incrementally building presentations or adding slides to template-based decks.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Required Description PPTX_FILE Yes Input presentation file

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Required Default Description --output -o Yes Output file path --title Yes Slide title --bullets No Bullet points (can specify multiple times) --layout No Auto-detect Layout index to use --help -h No Show help and exit

docs.title: Add a slide with bullets
docs.text:
power add deck.pptx -o deck.pptx --title "New Slide" \
    --bullets "First point" \
    --bullets "Second point" \
    --bullets "Third point"

docs.title: Add a title-only slide
docs.text: power add deck.pptx -o updated.pptx --title "Discussion"

docs.title: Specify layout
docs.text: power add deck.pptx -o deck.pptx --title "Custom" --layout 5

docs.title: Chain multiple adds
docs.text:
power add deck.pptx -o deck.pptx --title "Slide 2" --bullets "Point A"
power add deck.pptx -o deck.pptx --title "Slide 3" --bullets "Point B"
power add deck.pptx -o deck.pptx --title "Slide 4" --bullets "Point C"

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
On success:

Added slide: New Slide
Total slides: 5

On error:

Error: [error message]

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The --bullets option can be specified multiple times for multiple bullet points
  • If --layout is not specified, Power CLI auto-detects an appropriate content layout
  • Use power inspect to see available layout indices in your template
  • The input and output can be the same file to modify in place

docs.title: Layout Detection
docs.text:
When --layout is not specified, Power CLI searches for layouts in this order:

  1. Layouts with "content" in the name
  2. Layouts with a body/object placeholder
  3. Falls back to layout index 1

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• power remove - Remove slides
  • power generate - Generate multiple slides from YAML
  • power inspect - View available layouts

docs.title: power cloud
docs.text: Generate presentations via the cloud API instead of locally.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The power cloud command group allows you to generate presentations using the deployed Power API service. This is useful when you want to:

  • Generate presentations without installing all dependencies locally
  • Use the API from environments where python-pptx is difficult to install
  • Integrate with CI/CD pipelines or other automated workflows

docs.title: Subcommands
docs.text: Command Description power cloud health Check API health status power cloud generate Generate presentation via cloud power cloud inspect Inspect template via cloud

docs.title: Default API URL
docs.text:
By default, commands use the deployed Cloud Run service:

https://power-api-944767079044.us-central1.run.app

docs.title: Custom API URL
docs.text:
Override the API URL using:

Command Line FlagEnvironment Variable 
power cloud --api-url http://localhost:8080 health

export POWER_API_URL=http://localhost:8080
power cloud health

docs.title: power cloud health
docs.text: Check the cloud API health status.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: power cloud health

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
$ power cloud health
API Status: healthy
Version: 0.1.7
URL: https://power-api-944767079044.us-central1.run.app

docs.text: Generate a presentation via the cloud API.

docs.title: Arguments

docs.title: Options

power cloud generate slides.yaml -o themed.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx

Generated via cloud: presentation.pptx
Size: 45,983 bytes

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
The cloud commands handle common errors gracefully:

Error Cause Solution "Cannot connect to API" API unreachable Check URL and network "Request timed out" Slow response Try again or use local generation "HTTP 500" Server error Check API logs or report issue

docs.title: Local Development
docs.text:
To test against a local API server:

# Start local server
uvicorn power.api:app --reload --port 8080

# Use local server
power cloud --api-url http://localhost:8080 health

docs.title: power create
docs.text: Create a new presentation with a title slide.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: power create OUTPUT [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Creates a new PowerPoint presentation with a title slide. Optionally uses a template file for styling.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Required Description OUTPUT Yes Path for the generated .pptx file

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Default Description --template -t None Template .pptx file to use --title "Untitled Presentation" Presentation title --subtitle "" Presentation subtitle --author "" Author name (stored in file properties) --help -h Show help and exit

docs.title: Basic presentation
docs.text: power create my_deck.pptx --title "Q1 Report"

docs.title: With template
docs.text: power create themed.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx --title "Galaxy Theme"

docs.title: Full options
docs.text:
power create report.pptx \
    --template Corporate.pptx \
    --title "Annual Report" \
    --subtitle "Fiscal Year 2024" \
    --author "John Smith"

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
On success:

Created presentation: my_deck.pptx

On error:

Error: [error message]

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• If a template is specified, the template's existing slides are cleared before adding the title slide
  • The author is stored in the PowerPoint file's core properties
  • The output file is overwritten if it already exists

docs.text:

docs.title: power generate
docs.text: Generate a presentation from a YAML or JSON specification file.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: power generate INPUT_FILE -o OUTPUT [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Reads a YAML or JSON file describing the presentation structure and generates a PowerPoint file. This is the most powerful command for creating complex presentations programmatically.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Required Description INPUT_FILE Yes YAML (.yaml, .yml) or JSON (.json) specification file

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Required Description --output -o Yes Output .pptx file path --template -t No Template .pptx file to use --help -h No Show help and exit

docs.title: Supported Slide Types
docs.text: Type Description Required Fields title Title slide title section Section header title content Bullet points title, bullets table Data table title, headers, data chart Bar/line/pie chart title, chart_type, categories, series image Image slide title, image blank Empty slide (none)

docs.title: Basic generation
docs.text: power generate slides.yaml -o presentation.pptx

docs.title: With template
docs.text: power generate slides.yaml -o presentation.pptx -t Galaxy.pptx

docs.title: From JSON
docs.text: power generate config.json -o output.pptx

docs.title: Minimal YAML
docs.text:
title: My Presentation

  - type: content
    title: Overview
    bullets:
      - First point
      - Second point

docs.text:
title: Quarterly Report
subtitle: Q4 2024

slides:
  - type: section
    title: Financial Results

  - type: content
    title: Highlights
    bullets:
      - Revenue up 25%
      - New markets entered
      - Team expanded
    note: Speaker notes go here

  - type: table
    title: Key Metrics
    headers: [Metric, Q3, Q4, Change]
    data:
      - [Revenue, "$2.1M", "$2.6M", "+24%"]
      - [Users, "10K", "15K", "+50%"]

  - type: chart
    title: Revenue Trend
    chart_type: bar
    categories: [Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4]
    series:
      2023: [100, 120, 140, 160]
      2024: [150, 180, 210, 260]

  - type: image
    title: Product Screenshot
    image: images/screenshot.png
    width: 10
    height: 5
    left: 1.5
    top: 1.8

  - type: content
    title: With Image
    bullets:
      - Feature one
      - Feature two
    image: images/feature.png
    image_width: 4
    image_left: 8
    image_top: 2

  - type: title
    title: Thank You
    subtitle: Questions?

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
On success:

Generated presentation: presentation.pptx
  Slides: 8

On error:

Error: [error message]

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• A top-level title creates an automatic title slide
  • Use power inspect to see available layouts in your template
  • Image paths are relative to the input file location

docs.title: power inspect
docs.text: Inspect a PowerPoint template or presentation.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: power inspect PPTX_FILE [OPTIONS]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Displays information about a PowerPoint file including available layouts, placeholders, and slide dimensions. Essential for understanding template structure before generating presentations.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Required Description PPTX_FILE Yes PowerPoint file to inspect

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Description --json Output as JSON instead of formatted text --help -h Show help and exit

docs.title: Basic inspection
docs.text: power inspect Galaxy.pptx

docs.title: JSON output
docs.text: power inspect template.pptx --json

docs.title: Pipe to jq for processing
docs.text: power inspect Galaxy.pptx --json | jq '.layouts[].name'

docs.title: Layout Reference
docs.text:
Common PowerPoint layout indices:

Index Layout Name Use Case 0 Title Slide Opening/closing slides 1 Title and Content Standard content slides 2 Section Header Section dividers 3 Two Content Side-by-side content 4 Comparison Before/after, pros/cons 5 Title Only Charts, tables, custom 6 Blank Full custom control

Note

Layout indices and names vary by template. Always use power inspect to check your specific template.

docs.title: Placeholder Types
docs.text: Type Description TITLE Slide title SUBTITLE Slide subtitle BODY Main content area OBJECT General content placeholder PICTURE Image placeholder TABLE Table placeholder CHART Chart placeholder

docs.title: Finding the right layout
docs.text:
Before using power generate with a custom layout:

# Check available layouts
power inspect MyTemplate.pptx

# Use the layout name in YAML
# slides:
#   - type: content
#     layout: "Title and Content 1"

docs.title: Understanding picture placeholders
docs.text: power inspect Corporate.pptx | grep -i picture

docs.title: Scripting with JSON
docs.text:
# Get all layout names
power inspect template.pptx --json | jq -r '.layouts[].name'

# Count layouts
power inspect template.pptx --json | jq '.layout_count'

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
Interactive mode currently supports:

  • Title slides (created automatically)
  • Content slides with bullets

For tables, charts, and images, use power generate with a YAML file.

1. Start with a template - Use -t to apply corporate branding

docs.title: power remove
docs.text: Remove a slide from a presentation.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: power remove PPTX_FILE SLIDE_INDEX -o OUTPUT

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Removes a slide at the specified index from a PowerPoint presentation. Indices are 0-based (first slide is 0).

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Required Description PPTX_FILE Yes Input presentation file SLIDE_INDEX Yes 0-based index of slide to remove

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Required Description --output -o Yes Output file path --help -h No Show help and exit

docs.title: Remove the first slide
docs.text: power remove deck.pptx 0 -o deck_trimmed.pptx

docs.title: Remove the third slide (index 2)
docs.text: power remove presentation.pptx 2 -o presentation.pptx

docs.title: Remove multiple slides
docs.text:
# Remove slide at index 5, then 3, then 1
# (work backwards to avoid index shifting)
power remove deck.pptx 5 -o deck.pptx
power remove deck.pptx 3 -o deck.pptx
power remove deck.pptx 1 -o deck.pptx

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
On success:

Removed slide 2
Slides: 10 -> 9

On error (index out of range):

Error: Slide index 15 out of range

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
Index Shifting

When removing multiple slides, remember that indices shift after each removal. Remove from highest index to lowest to avoid confusion.

docs.title: Example: Removing slides 2, 4, and 6
docs.text:
Wrong way (indices shift):

power remove deck.pptx 2 -o deck.pptx  # Removes original slide 2
power remove deck.pptx 4 -o deck.pptx  # Removes original slide 5!
power remove deck.pptx 6 -o deck.pptx  # Removes original slide 8!

Right way (work backwards):

power remove deck.pptx 6 -o deck.pptx  # Removes original slide 6
power remove deck.pptx 4 -o deck.pptx  # Removes original slide 4
power remove deck.pptx 2 -o deck.pptx  # Removes original slide 2

docs.title: Slide Index Reference
docs.text: Slide Index First 0 Second 1 Third 2 Last (of 10) 9

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• power add - Add slides
  • power inspect - View slide count

docs.title: power replace
docs.text: Replace placeholder text throughout a presentation.

docs.title: Synopsis
docs.text: power replace PPTX_FILE REPLACEMENTS... -o OUTPUT

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Finds and replaces {{PLACEHOLDER}} text patterns throughout all slides in a presentation. Useful for filling template presentations with dynamic content.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Required Description PPTX_FILE Yes Input presentation file REPLACEMENTS Yes One or more KEY=VALUE pairs

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Required Description --output -o Yes Output file path --help -h No Show help and exit

docs.title: Single replacement
docs.text:
power replace template.pptx NAME=John -o filled.pptx

This replaces all occurrences of {{NAME}} with John.

docs.title: Multiple replacements
docs.text:
power replace report.pptx \
    TITLE="Q1 Report" \
    DATE="January 2024" \
    AUTHOR="Jane Smith" \
    -o q1_report.pptx

docs.title: Values with spaces
docs.text:
Use quotes for values containing spaces:

power replace template.pptx "COMPANY=Acme Corporation" -o filled.pptx

docs.title: From variables
docs.text:
NAME="John Doe"
DATE=$(date +%Y-%m-%d)
power replace template.pptx "NAME=$NAME" "DATE=$DATE" -o output.pptx

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
On success:

Replaced 3 placeholder(s)
Saved to: filled.pptx

On error:

Error: Invalid replacement format: invalid (expected KEY=VALUE)

docs.title: Template Format
docs.text:
In your PowerPoint template, use double curly braces for placeholders:

Welcome, {{NAME}}!

Report Date: {{DATE}}
Prepared by: {{AUTHOR}}

After running:

power replace template.pptx NAME=John DATE=2024-01-15 AUTHOR=Jane -o output.pptx

The output will contain:

Welcome, John!

Report Date: 2024-01-15
Prepared by: Jane

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Placeholder names are case-sensitive ({{Name}} ≠ {{NAME}})
  • Placeholders can appear in titles, body text, tables, and notes
  • Unreplaced placeholders remain as-is in the output
  • The replacement searches all text frames in all shapes

docs.title: Dynamic Reports
docs.text:
Create a template with placeholders:

  • {{QUARTER}} - Q1, Q2, Q3, Q4
  • {{YEAR}} - 2024
  • {{REVENUE}} - $2.5M
  • {{GROWTH}} - +25%

Generate reports for each quarter:

power replace quarterly.pptx QUARTER=Q1 YEAR=2024 REVENUE="$2.1M" GROWTH="+20%" -o q1.pptx
power replace quarterly.pptx QUARTER=Q2 YEAR=2024 REVENUE="$2.3M" GROWTH="+22%" -o q2.pptx

docs.title: Personalized Presentations
docs.text:
for name in Alice Bob Carol; do
    power replace welcome.pptx NAME=$name -o "welcome_${name}.pptx"
done

docs.title: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
# In a GitHub Action or CI pipeline
power replace release.pptx \
    VERSION=${{ github.ref_name }} \
    DATE=$(date +%Y-%m-%d) \
    COMMIT=${{ github.sha }} \
    -o release_notes.pptx
